climbs.name: Unnamed
climbs.fa: John Butler, Carlo Torres, or Luke Laeser, early 90s

content.description: The furthest N (left) route on the E wall of the Pit.  Ascends a pocketed slab on great rock.  A bit on the short side.  This route used to be a TR, but was recently bolted.
content.protection: 3 red bolts to 2 BA with fixed biners.
content.location: The first route on the left as you enter the pit.

climbs.name: Unknown Wide Crack
climbs.fa: John Butler, Carlo Torres, or Luke Laeser, early 90s

content.description: The wide crack between Odor Takeda and Gralisa Leen.  Some loose rubble in the crack.  The others in the Pit are better.
content.protection: Rack of cams from 2-4".  Bigger (#5 and #6 camalots) useful too, but probably not necessary.  You can reach the anchors for the adjacent routes without difficulty.
content.location: Obvious wide crack between Odor Takeda and Gralisa Leen on the West side of the Pit

content.description: Start on gear until the crack widens and becomes pretty loose. There are no anchors, so people generally veer left and use the remaining bolts/anchors on Gralisa Leen.
content.location: The finger-sized crack just left of the thunderbird painting.

content.description: Crack to the left (S) of The Odor Takeda.  Climbs up through a hole and eventually joins up with The Odor Takeda.
content.protection: Standard rack up to 2".  There are places for some larger pieces, but not necessary.  You can finish the route as a sport route on The Odor Takeda, but there are places for pro the whole way if you want to skip the bolts near the top.

content.description: The furthest S route on the W wall of the Pit.  This route begins up a pocketed slab, maneuvering through a couple of horizontal breaks on mostly great pockets and some big crimps.  The rock deteriorates a bit near the top.
content.location: The 2nd bolted route encountered on the right wall from the approach.

content.description: Much harder than it looks, this route climbs the beautiful panel left of the thunderbird painting.  Its possible to stem into the left crack, or grab the crack, but for full value, sitck to the face.  Some tiny pockets and sharp crimps split up great rests in the two horizontal breaks.  The crux comes getting your feet over the lip of the 6 inch roof at mid-height.  Some chossy rock at the top detracts a bit, but overall a great route.
content.location: First bolted route encountered on the right wall, or the furthest N route on the W wall.

climbs.name: Fay Drostenson
climbs.fa: Butler/Laeser/Torres (solo-early 90s), bolted by Walt Wehner, Day Frostenson, and Theo Takeda, 7/2000

content.description: The S-most route on the E wall of the Pit.  This route ascends a short overhang on killer pockets to a good ledge.  A final 10 foot section on small, sharp pockets and crimps leads to the chains.  One of the few White Rock routes with morning shade.
content.protection: 3 bolts to 2 BA.  May want to stick clip 1st bolt.
content.location: The 2nd route approached on the left side of the Pit.

content.description:
The Pit is an enclosed pit-type area just north of the Main Wall at Gallows Edge. Four bolted routes and a couple of crack climbs are found in The Pit. It also offers some nice circle traverse bouldering inside.  Because it's enclosed it makes for a nice shady retreat in summer heat. 

  An good guide to download is found here: lamountaineers.org/pdf/The_â€¦
